coredata.dc:creator: Balucani, U.
Vallauri, R.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The relative motion of atomic pairs in dense fluids is investigated in the short-time regime bolh theoretically and by computer experiments. It is discussed how previous descriptions of the time-dependent distribution functions must be modified in order to account for the dynamical effects of the interactions.

Introduction The relative motion of atomic pairs in simple fluids can be described by a tune-dependent distribu- tion function G-,(R,R', t) which is proportional to the joint probability thai two particles are separated by R' at tune t if their separation was R at time t = 0. This function is the simplest of a class of time-depen- dent distribution functions important in interaction- induced phenomena [1] and has recently been in- vestigated by means of computer simulation experi- ments [2—4]. It has also been demonstrated that a modified version of the "constant acceleration ap- proximation" (CAA) firstly introduced by Bloom and Oppenheun [5] describes exactly the short-time behaviour at least at low densities [6]. On the other hand, at long tunes the diffusional character of the motion allows one to infer a suitable model for G^(R,R'. t) which seems to account for most of the features discussed in ref. [3]. At liquid densities Haan [4] has successfully compared his molecular- dynamics (MD) results with a time-dependent dis- tribution obtained by a numerical integration of a Smoluchowski equation and modeled in such a way that the initial spread is taken into account. Here we present new MD data which emphasize the short-time regime ofG^ and provide the defini- tive test for a correct description of the initial start in the CAA framework at all densities. In particular, it is found that the physical quantities under exami- nation are affected by the interactions not only through the effects implied by the static pair distribu- tion function. Moreover, the analytical expression for G-, derived in the following is consistent with the short-time extension of the Smoluchowski equation introduced in ref. [4]. 2. Conclusion In this communication it has been shown that the short-time evolution of atomic pairs at high densities can be satisfactorily accounted provided that the time-dependent distribution function includes the dynamical effects of the interactions. As one expects, the latter effects are crucial for all properties in which small separations are emphasized. A consistent theo- ry of the time-dependent distribution function out- side the short-time regime clearly requires further in- vestigations. In this sense a physical model like that introduced by Haan [4] starting from a diffusive- hke Smoluchowski equation can be helpful as it in- corporates in an "ad hoc" way the correct dynamics at short times. Again, whenever large separations have a predominant weight, simple models based on un- 78 Volume 74, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 August 1980 correlated particle propagation are found to yield reasonable results [3] even in the long-time regime.
